title: Vanara Adventurer (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Though generally staying within the confines of Hanuman's court in Vaikuntha, for some vanara, the lure of adventure in the material planes is too difficult to resist. Bright, inquisitive, and remarkably agile, the vanara take quickly to the technological advancements of the Known Worlds without losing their intimacy with magic. This character was modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%. Get a start on your 3D-printed fantasy army! We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

title: Underslung Power Supply Mount for Vision Prusa Mendel Printers

description.text:
This power supply holder was designed for the Vision iteration of Prusa Mendel printer which uses thick acrylic sidewalls. I wanted a better way to mount the 115mm wide power supply unit that was also relatively visually appealing.  
It requires a 200mm build plate and needs clamping bolts (I used 25mm M3).  
The images above are of my first print - this has since been tweaked and will look slightly different.  
Depending on your setup you may need to use the risers to lift your printer as by default the PSU is ~10mm lower than the print walls.  
There are some changes I would like to make but have not yet for time reasons. Included are the Sketchup files. I would stretch the rear arms out to be as wide as the front arms for ease of installation.

title: Arca Swiss clamp compatible phone mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Every once in a while, I just want to stick my phone on my tripod. Odd thing though, my phone is the only camera in the house without an Arca Swiss compatible plate on it. Hey, we can't have that! And bolting a small Arca plate onto a phone mount of some kind sounded a bit too... I dunno. Not 3d printed. =) The clamp fits a phone from the size of a naked iPhone 4 to a Nexus 6p in a Speck case. The images are for a Nexus 6p in a Speck case and a naked Moto X. The base is 38mm x 39mm.
The slider is 55mm long.
Clamp full closed is 60mm from top to bottom of both arc openings.
There's a groove that goes all the way around. The groove is 1.2mm deep. (I use a .4mm nozzle so...)
There are two 2.75mm diameter holes that are 6.5mm deep on the bottom to accept 3mm diameter socket head cap screws for anti drop/slide protection.
There is an unthreaded hole that can be used with a 1/4 20 screw. Be sure to tap this hole before use. Take it easy when using this mount option. It's not a great idea threading a metal screw into extruded plastic, but its always perfect sometimes. The rubber band you use should definitely be less than 190mm in circumference. ***Update Feb 3, 2016:
Spaced the 3mm screw holes on the bottom a bit wider apart. It was a bit too close together when I measured out my clamp with some calipers.
Uploaded higher mesh files.
Measured out my plates on my cameras, and their bases measure out more like ~39mm. Weird. I may resize the base to 39mm x 39mm. This may not matter depending on what kind of clamp you have. Something to consider though. ***Update Feb 4, 2016:
Printed one out, and made some changes.
Made the groove 1.2mm deep all the way around. The rubber band seats a bit better.
Changed the arcs to be 13mm wide by 5mm deep. This accommodates my Nexus 6p in a Speck candyshell case much better.
Made the 3mm screw holes deeper after I gained some space by changing the arc dimensions. I apparently don't have any 4mm long 3mm screws, but plenty of 5mm ones.
Made the dimensions of the base 39mm x 38mm. It fit just fine in my clamp at 38mm x 38mm, but a lil bit extra never hurts.
Put a "max" line on the slider bar. I have no idea if that's the true max, but it's notes that 1/3rd of the slider is left.
I used a rubber band that had a 135mm circumference, and it worked great. A little tough to get the Nexus 6p in place, but still worked fine. ***Update April 26, 2016:
I was happy with my mount, until I used a cheap tripod that didn't have an Arca Swiss clamp. So cheap that a new clamp would cost more than the tripod.
Added a 1/4-20 sized hole to the bottom of the mount. I don't have an appropriately sized tap, so I used a stubby 1/4-20 bolt to thread it. That works, but it's definitely not ideal. Use a tap instead. ***Update October 25, 2017:
c4v3man commented that maybe adding a rubber band groove to the clamp surfaces would be a good idea. A couple revisions later, and I think we've got something that works. ***Update October 26, 2017:
Since I was messing around with the model anyway, I figured it was time to do something I've wanted to do for a while. To decrease the "stack height" on top of my inexpensive flexy tripod, I slapped a 18.5mm ball clamp to the bottom of my phone mount. Epic. At least I think it is. ***Update January 13, 2018:
SuGrobi asked for a GoPro mount. I haven't printed this one, but it should work.

title: Vibrating Bowl Feeder V1.0 - Tooled for M3 Hex Nuts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to develop a 3d printable bowl feeder that was cheap and easy to make.
The industrial units are super cool - but just way too expensive and specialist for all you inventors and makers at home!
This wee unit was my first design in producing an open source alternative - it's not there yet, but will be soon. You can see it in action on my YouTube channel here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xXfcDdvP9jU So this really is a V1.0 - it works, but not reliably.
I really wanted to use an off the shelf DC motor to energize it, but the results were a bit disappointing.
The industrial units use a linear vibrator, and for good reason... This thing is noisy and temperamental. To make this run, I needed to stick the base down to the bench with double sided foam tape - screwing down too rigidly gave vibrations that were too aggressive and threw parts from the track.
The DC motor was controlled via an el cheapo 12V PWM controller from eBay and was a right pain to get dialed in correctly. If you want to have an experiment with this, I would suggest:
  • Scale the Vibro Spring parts to make different thicknesses (and therefore stiffnesses)
  • Investigate a linear vibrator moving up & down - scrap the DC motor idea.
    • I will be releasing a V1.1 once it is working - you can follow me here or on YouTube for all the updates! As far as I can see, this is the first working 3d printed feeder of it's type uploaded on the internet - pretty damn cool really. If you think this is a neat project, and do end up experimenting please share your results for everyone to see!

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Dense

Notes: I printed this without rafts and at 0.2mm layer height. The parts have all been designed to print without supports. For the actual bowl, the finer the layer height the better as you need to get the track very smooth after printing.

Acetone, so much acetone.... To get a really nice surface on the track, I gave the inside of the bowl a sand and a super aggressive acetone vapor bath. On my second bowl print, I actually just sanded and then rubbed the track down with a rag soaked in Acetone and this worked just as well, but was a lot easier. This track smoothing was key to success. I had absolutely no luck at all getting the parts to progress up the track until I had it mirror smooth. You will also need some M3x12 Socket Head Cap Screws to attach the bowl and motor mount to the vibrator. The screws seem to self tap into the printed holes just fine. The motor mount tends to slip as printed, so I installed the motor and then used electrical tape to tension around the claws.

title: Storage Port Hole Cover / Storage Can for a Cystler Man-O-War Sail Boat

description.text:
One day after a day of sailing, I couldn't find my truck keys, that I had put in the storage area in the bow.  At first I thought I had lost them in the lake, but fortunately they had just bounced to a far corner of the bow.   After that scare,  I decided I needed a better place to store my valuables on the boat.  
This cover replaces the stock cover for the storage port holes.  Attached to the cover is a can that screws on.  It's a good place to store keys, small parts, certificates, etc.  
While I designed it for my boat, it may fit others.  It's designed for a 5.1 inch diameter hole with trim about 6.5 inch diameter.   My printer has a 6 inch limit so part of the trim is not covered, but it doesn't seem to be a problem since the hole is still plugged.  (The Red one is the final model, the green one covered less area.)  
I've included the SolidWorks files if anyone wants to modify it.  
I have not performed a float test, or water proof test, but I'd guess this would float for quite a while if dropped in the lake.
I suggest printing with 2 shells to help make the compartment more water proof.  No support or rafting is necessary.

ICBob is a bi-ped robot remixed from Bob and Arduped to take advantage of our chosen controller and power source. This is a project of the Teen Imagineering Club at the Bridgeville Delaware Public Library You will need to print
1x - icbob_base
1x - icbob_shell (print with support)
2x - icbob_knee
1x - icbob_left_foot
1x - icbob_right_foot We have included Arduino sketches to get him moving.
Make sure you get Korman's VarSpeedServo library found on our Instructable Here is a video of ICBob walking https://youtu.be/BO2iY5OFvsk
All eleven ICBobs moving about https://youtu.be/YU_b7mdniIE You can see how it all comes together in our Instructable http://www.instructables.com/id/ICBob-a-Bob-Inspired-Biped-Robot/

This thing needs to be printed in 4 parts, one for each of the 4 major colors of the Google Chrome logo.  Once printed, the parts screw together to make a 3D version of the logo (you can choose spherical or hemisphere version).

I've included STL files for 50 mm diameter hemisphere as well as full spherical version: chrome--50s.stl - spherical parts
chrome--50.stl - hemi-spherical parts Note that the spherical version needs to be printed with support. The chrome.scad file is parameterized to make any size logo, and can optionally print a whole sphere (vs. a hemispherical version).

title: Luggage Rack bracket for rear/tail light

description.text:
A clamp to attach a rear bike light to an older style luggage rack.
Fits racks with 8mm bars, approximately 85mm centres. There is a few mm of play either way. If not, stretch/shrink objects slightly or use a dremel. 'socket' for the light's clip is about 9mm across. Use a fair amount(40% seems good) of infill and perimeters for strength.
Screws are about 3mm across the thread and 11.5mm long. No idea what their size is. Photos show a slightly older version with holes filled in with nail polish, model changed to make the top screw holes blind so this isn't needed. Original version had the screws coming in from the top, new version is more annoying to install but keeps water out of the screws.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=boCuzmQPn8M Full Tutorial:
https://learn.adafruit.com/raspberry-pi-pipboy-3000/overview?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=videodescrip&utm_campaign=3dprinting Download Source:
http://a360.co/1S1L8xX 3D print and build your own functional Pipboy 3000 using a Raspberry Pi and Adafruit 3.5" PiTFT. The pypboy python program for the Raspberry Pi features OSM for map data which allows you to browse your terrain rendered in glorious retro green graphics. It features an audio amp + speaker with the actual score and background music from Fallout 4. An analog rotary switch lets you switch between different modes in the pypboy python program. The 3D printed enclosure has cutouts for most of the IO ports for the Raspberry Pi, so you add your favorite peripheral like a WiFi dongle, keyboard and mouse. The 2200mAh battery can be recharged over USB and fits inside an aesthetically looking cylindrical case. Details like the super bright yellow LED, rotary encoder, speaker grill and faux gauges really make this look like a Pipboy 3000 Mark IV.

A 90MM X Micro Quadcopter frame for FPV fun. This Frame was inspired by the Impulse Alien frame and the Lumenier Raceblade. The frame is assembled in 3 pieces. Main plate is designed to be lite and durable 3MM thick. Cut outs to attach rubber bands to mount the battery underneath. Accessory plate to mount all electronics and is only .5mm thick. Top Plate with slot and hole in the back so your FPV antenna will sit vertical for better reception 1MM thick. Designed for 8.5mm motors
Designed in AutoCad 2016 Student edition. Frame weight with standoffs is 12g My complete quad weighs in at 46g and 56 with 350MAH battery 2/4/2016 Uploaded a new frame that is stronger. Redesigned how the rubber band attaches to the frame giving it more support to the center of the quad. Added supports around the motor and arms for improved strength. Labeled strongstrong
2/3/16 Uploaded a short and deep camera top plate. Required hardware. 4 x 10mm x 2mm stand offs with nuts and screws.

Printer:

Folgertech 2020 I3

Infill:

25

Notes: Printed at 25% infill to keep the frame light. Frame has some flex but that helps in a crash instead snapping.

description.text: Want to have a 1:12 film theater in your home? This little guy will get you started off. Well, it's not that small - it's 160mm tall (6.25"). It's inspired by the classic DeVry 10 projector, but not intended to be a perfect replica; I just wanted to capture its retro/art deco style. Designed with Notepad++ and OpenScad on Windows 10. See more of our designs at rabbitengineering.com

What to print Print one of each STL, except for wheel.stl (do two of those), handle.stl (do four of those) and lever.stl (do 5 or 6 of those, they go where ever you like). Paint the main components in some cool retro color (I chose chromate green; I don't know what color the originals were, as I could find no color photos); then paint the detail parts in silver (see the photos for reference). I also used a silver Sharpie to do some distressing/weathering. Finally, use cyanoacrylate (superglue) to glue the main body components (the green parts in my photos), but taking care to place film_collar between film and top_segment as shown in the pictures. One that has set, go ahead and glue the little details - you can copy my layout, or get creative.

description.text:
Support and dampener for Folgertech Kossel, or any printer with 2020 aluminum beams. For a delta printer make six. You can do three, but you have to be careful not to put the whole weight of the printer on only one while setting it up because it will deform (I accidentally found this out first hand) . Basically distribute the weight evenly.The pip in the center fits into the groove of 2020. The shape allows for relatively easy printing while being both strong and flexible enough to dampen vibration of the system. My printer used to make all kinds of noise when printing, now all I hear is the fan cooling the heatsink. Edit:
Added STEP and STL for an update with a 3mm and 4mm hole for securing it

Folgertech Kossel 2020

Solid

Also printed PLA @ 200C on heated PEI bed at @ 60C with success.

description.text: It's sometimes hard to see what the extruder is doing if you are remotely monitoring it through a webcam — is it feeding, or retracting, or has it stopped completely? The extruder's movements will be more obvious if you slip this cow-themed indicator onto your extruder motor's shaft. This feed-wheel was designed to fit the Printrbot Simple Metal, but will also fit any motor with a 5 mm OD shaft. This design was derived from Richard Schumann's Cow icon from The Noun Project.

• Cowface Feedwheel.stl is a friction-fit onto the motor shaft. It includes a block for friction-fitting an optional M3 threaded insert (4 mm OD) to fit an M3 grub screw. Drop the insert into the hole horizontally, and then use a longer M3 screw to pull it into the block. Adding the grub screw gives this feedwheel enough grip to be used as a handle for turning the shaft by hand for manual extrusion.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10 %

Notes: Print this face-down as supplied. Your bottom layer needs to be perfect, or else you will lose the outline of the cow face. If you can't do this, then you can print it with the cow face-up, but you'll need supports.

Grab a fine (not ultra-fine) Sharpie and carefully use the side of the tip to outline the edges and details of the cow's face.
If you are having trouble fitting this onto your motor shaft, dip the stem of the print in just-boiled water to soften it.

18 Aug 2017
  • Redrawn in Fusion 360. It is now approx. 3 mm wider all around to make it easier to grip and turn for manual extrusion.
  • My previous design for the M3 insert/grub screw was very bad because I relied on the insert to grab onto the plastic and stay there — but the AliExpress inserts are straight-knurled and have no grip, so they simply got pushed out as I tightened the grub screw. In this new design, the insert is trapped inside a block.
    • 16 Feb 2016
  • Added grub screw version; I stripped the soft PLA on the original version by using it as a handle for turning the extruder shaft manually, so this should make the object more robust for this purpose.
  • Increased the ID of the motor shaft mounts by 0.10 mm.
    • 3 Feb 2016
  • Initial release.

title: Ultimate printer torture test
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Test your printer to the maximum with this model, it features all you can really imagine what your printer may struggle to print with from sharp corners right through to very intricate detailed slopes.

author: Gluon45

description.text:
The attached is a couple of parts I have modified from others.
The blower I have added two 5mm LED holders, So it lights up the nozzle and work piece.
The extruder carrier, started out as a self contained unit that had bearing holders built in, but I found another bearing holder which was much more suitable (thanks toolson,) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1036871
I wanted to experiment swapping jobs between an MK8 and Bowden, so I used "toolson's" base and Bowden, and added this MK8 to pickup the existing mounting holes in the base.
I have also added a fan mount out front of the extruder, removing the heat sink, to provide better access to changing the filament, this fan blows over the 6mm stem and the bottom half of the aluminum extruder. I have added a mount for the 15mmcable chain to tidy up all the cables, and also a tab to operate the limit switch or put a bolt in it to adjust the left stop point.

I've been programming for quite a few years now, and since the beginning of time (programming my Commodore P.E.T.), I could not remember binary bit patterns to save my life!
This thing gives me the ability to print out binary representations of numbers.  That gives me something nice and tactile that I can look at, pick up, and play around with.
Perhaps if I had this as a toy when I was younger, I would not have such problems remembering binary encodings because the memories would have been cemented in something physical.
Within the test_boolean.scad file, you will find the module: display_binary(number, bits, withplate)
You give it a number, and the number of bits you want to display, and whether you want a base plate attached or not.
And out comes your binary representation of your number.
If you care to look deeper, you can take a look at the boolean.scad file.  In there you will find some useful bit banging operators like RSHIFT, LSHIFT, BIT, BTEST, 32BITAND, 32BITNOT, 32BITXOR, 32BITOR, and other boolean algebra thingies.  These might be useful for other things some day.
In particular, you could perform an operation, and print the result of the operation tactally.

1) Download the boolean.scad, and test_boolean.scad files
2) Enter parameters into the display_binary() module
3) Look at the pretty picture
4) Generate .stl
5) Print
6) Rejoice!

description.header: Note - there will be no further updates to this page. Any further updates will be on the FB2020 Github page - https://github.com/AxMod3DPrint/FB2020
description.text: Originally based on the Fusebox, this printer now has become a design in it's own right. Most major parts have been redesigned from the ground up or have been overhauled in some way.

description.header: Should you want to buy a full kit or buy the printed parts they are now available on
description.text: https://www.axmod3dprint.com

The Ethos of the Fusebox was to keep parts pricing low, which at the beginning of this project, was the same aim, however, it is now to improve the FB2020 to a point where it's pretty much it's fool proof and highly reliable. I want it to the point where anyone with a set of Allen keys can put it together. I'm happy with the frame rigidity, yes, it's not as rigid as it could be, but I still want to try to keep costs down where possible, by using printed plastic parts this helps a little. I've added a list of upcoming changes below.
All files should be orientated correctly for printing. Any file marked Culain is an original file from Culain's design and no physical changes apart from mirroring and orientating correctly have been made.
All bolt, rod and hot end holes on the STLS for the Carriage and Carriers have a 0.4mm tolerance. If you need less or more, grab the SCAD files. There is a setting in there to change it.

The best way I have found is to loosen off the motors so they are on the end of the bolts in the Y direction. Pull the belts as taught as you can manually then tighten the motors back up to bring the belts to full tension. I'm working on a better tensioning system currently. https://youtu.be/WNDfNemOfFM - Gayer-Anderson Cat in Whiter Generic PLA at 80mm/s at 0.1mm layer height. https://youtu.be/yOhGpVYnDCI - Aztec Chief in ColorFabb NGEN at 80mm/s at 0.28 Layer Height https://youtu.be/bmPf83OeyGA - Printing the Rigid coupler in ColorFabb NGEN at 80mm/s & 150mm/s Travel - retraction settings were being worked on, so the print is a little stringy.. https://youtu.be/XaOWR-UzrOI- 2nd Print - #3DBenchy Timelapse.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

FB2020 CoreXY

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.28

Infill:

50-70%

Notes: Print as orientated, Support needed for Extruder Carriage, Carriers, Idlers, layer fan assembly and right side idler rod mount. All parts need to be printed at 70% infill for strength with the exception of the Bowden tube clips at 100% infill and RAMPS mount and Z endstop mount at 15-20%

So anyway, I'm starting again with this implementation, it does seem well supported too! This will be my first build, I have a Malyan M150 as my first printer, I'll be using that to print the parts needed for this one.  Fingers crossed, I'll end up with a better, faster 3D printer which won't cost the earth :-)

comments.text: If you have the Endstop at the back of the Bot, then you need to home to Max on Y. X0 Y0 is the front left of the printer. I've uploaded the latest version. It probably won't work out of the box as all directions are inverted in the firmware, so you may need to flip the connections

comments.text: The teeth need to slot into the teeth on the belt. There needs to be a twist in the outside length on the Y axis to make sure the smooth side of the the belts runs on the bearings. The short bolts were from the original design by Culain, yes they can be longer with a lock nut on the opposite end.

comments.text: The design is pretty much final. The tweaks to the extruder carriage were mainly just to tighten up the belt clips and allow for printing tolerences in the hot end mount and clamp.
comments.author: meoutside

comments.text: Hi again AxMod. Just a quick question on the timing belt. Does it definitely need to be 3 meters long or would 2 meters suffice? My wait time from Amazon for a 3 meter belt is about 2-4 weeks. Thanks again.
comments.author: AnthonyArevalo

comments.text: The belt runs are just over a meter so yes, it does need to be a 3 meter length. You're better off ordering from a dedicated online store than Amazon, you'll get it quicker.
comments.author: AnthonyArevalo

comments.text: Hi AxMod,
comments.author: Print_It_3D

comments.text: There's instructions on what needs supports in the info. As for guidance, all parts are printed at 0.28mm layer height. The Parts are a mix of ColorFabb NGEN and eSun PLA. 70% infill is more than enough. There are some structural parts that are printed at 50% on it as I forgot to change the infill and they're fine. Things like the RAMPS mount, Z endstop and spool holder can be printed as low as 10% and be fine.
comments.author: Print_It_3D

comments.text: Thanks for the details, much appreciated.
comments.author: AxMod3DPrint

comments.text:
Congratulations AxMod' things are looking good.
After getting it running what fine tuning or design changes are you planning?
Thanks for posting pics of your calibration cube even though it is not perfect. What do you think is the cause of the banding you are seing?
comments.author: meoutside

comments.text: Thanks. 3 Point levelling is going to happen, the 4 point is driving me nuts atm. Not sure what's causing the banding atm, although it's a lot better since I've made a change to the belt configuration and tightened them up. I've put a twist in along the long Y run on the outside, so the smooth side of the belt runs along all the idler bearings. The Extruder Carriage needs updating to match the the teeth of the belt. I ran a Yoda bust overnight and it came out really well and I've just run a couple of Marvins off just now which have come out brilliantly. There's still a bit of banding, but it's a hell of a lot better. I'll be posting pics later along with more updates.
comments.author: meoutside

comments.text: Looks like nice progress. Keep up the good work.

comments.text: Again, thanks a bunch for this. I'm in the middle of building and should probably have it done by tonight! I'll post pics once I do. Cheers!

comments.text: Awesome. Be good to see another FB2020 running. I will say that if you've built to the same dimensions as this one a 300mm leadscrew is too long as it fouls the extruder carriage, I'll probably be changing the vertical frame lengths to compensate for that and to allow for a larger build volume..

Figure this would be a fun thing to try. Normally ocarina are made by hollowing out a clay shape or slip casting to get a hollow form. They take a lot of time to make a one off. Lots of drying time. I figure what better use for a 3d printer. I have no idea on the tuning currently just trying to get it to play first. Improvements will come with input. Anyway have fun let me know how it goes. UPDATE: New voicing that works I am currently tuning the different bodies. New BODY Loaded! Working on finger hole adjustments. Test and input if you wish. I might move and narrow the voicing after a few tests. Usefully links:
http://www.greenverdugo.com/ocarina-making-tutorial/ocarina-making-15.html
Print.. Try to play and give some feedback for improvement.

This is a 3D printed business card. You don't need a dual extruder 3D printer to make your own, you can print it in any printer using the instructions below.

• Open the FreeCAD file and edit the text strings so the card contains your contact information.
  • Export to STL in FreeCAD
  • Slice with Cura. In the Plugins tab, choose ChangeFilamentAtZ the plugin. You have to pause the print at 1.1mm, where the letters start.
  • Print at good resolution. I've found that for the default text printing at 0.1mm works fine.

This is a design for a cover to keep those stray air currents from compromising my prints. You may have seen my much improved heavily modified printer - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47899 - In essence it is a Replicator 1 Dual with all the necessary fixes to get it to work well consistently. I have been meaning to finish the tranformation to carbonator for some time so I am both relieved and proud to announce that this is now complete. All panels and top cover were cut on my CNC router http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5632 from the supplied DXF files.
You will note that the HPB arms are from "bottleworks" - I highly recommend these. Other add-ons since I posted the first changes include: extruder enhancements, HPB replacement, borosilicate glass, three point levelling platform and some other stuff...which I hope to chronicle at some future date when my list of projects diminishes.
BTW - the tool holder rack at bottom right of the picture is still in the process of completing design - I will post the finished item when I am satisfied with the result.

Inspired by other Air 2 spool holders (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35915) and using VeimoX 's catia files which i imported into Autodesk Inventor
i designed these spool holders to use the existing screw holes used for the assembly brackets.
Replaced the original screws with 30 mm long ones ( M4) to accommodate the brackets base thickness.
Uses M8 rod X 265mm long to support the filament spool + 4 X M8 nuts & washers Quite happy to share the "Prusa Air 2" Inventor assembly / parts files if anybody is interested. Aside from importing the catia files i have constrained the parts in Inventor as well as added / edited some elements ( work in progress) to reflect my home printer . all comments welcome enjoy

Hagia Sophia was made by a team of students during the 3D Printing workshop @UTech Lab. Hagia Sophia is the eleventh monument out of fifteen monuments to be designed during the series of 3D printing workshops @UTech Lab. After each workshop, one monument is added to the Europe 3D Printed Map(thing:1002482) located in the ground floor of the lab.
Monuments already made include the Big Ben (thing:1041101), the Eiffel Tower (thing:1060135), the Parthenon (thing:1067082), the Belem Tower (thing:1099449), the Sagrada Familia (thing:1101544), the Colosseum (thing:1103617), the Pisa Tower (thing:1129396), the Brandenburg Gate (thing:1160276), Saint Basil's Cathedral (thing:1235054) and White Tower of Thessaloniki (thing:1297119). For more information, please visit our website:
http://eugenweb3.eugenfound.edu.gr/utech

description.text:
3DC is a simple, economic and covertible machine with a large working area, You can use it for milling, engraving or 3d printing. This project is all Open source. The working area is x=365mm y=255mm z=280mm using 490 mm rod for x and 370 mm rod for y and z. 8/02/2016 Fixed,optimized and uploaded all new parts;
14/03/2016 Redesigned all parts; more compact, 2x less material, 4x stable.

comments.author: evox

comments.text: They look like pretty standard parts. LM8uu linear bearings for the X&Y Axis, M8 rod for the shafts, either M8 threaded rod or 5/16" to drive the Y&Z-axis, the belt probably doesnt matter as long as you match it to a pulley that fits on your motor. motors look like nema17s, the Z axis is the only thing I can't say for certain, looks like aluminum rods but bigger than M8, M10? or 1/2? The couplers can be printed or you can use an old tubing trick with zipties.

It kind of looks like it is not supporting the flashlights weight in the photo, but the flashlight is fully supported by the clip. Enjoy!

I had some spare parts of a tertial lamp and used them for a youtube cellphone camera recording thing and a tool organizer mount thing.

I thought it could be interesting to watch a movie or tv show while exercising on the stationary bike, so I made a support for my tablet. There are 4 parts that should fit together, but it may be better to use glue in the joints. Using cyanoacrylate with bicarbonate produces instant welding.
I have included the source file (designed with FreeCAD) so you can change the dimensions in order to fit your own bike.
I also included a cylinder print sample in case you want to try if it fits on your bike. P.D. I had a problem with the printer and the printed cylinders are not completely straight, but in the designed part they are.

A card box to keep the cards from Runebound. Plenty of room for a few upcoming expansions. Fits sleeved cards.
The color effect on the lid was accomplished by switching to red PLA midway.
To 'attach' the lid to the box, I use magnets. Square 3x3x1 mm and Round 3 mm diameter with a height of 3 mm. Holes to put them in are already in the design. (See pictures)

title: 2x - Filament guide to avoid Jamming with non standard spool size

description.text:
--UPDATE oct 2013 - Added a new version with different designs and pictures installed . More easy to stick and provide better filament guidance. Print both element , one for right one for left.  
The original "simpler" design still available, but highly recommend new version. Not one problem since installed...  
I got plenty of issues with some spool and their filament that kept getting of the spool limits and locked itself between the back oft he makerbot and the spool itself. After few turn... just ruined the print. Check the pictures to understand what I mean.    So I designed this filament guide to kind of force the filament to be taken from the middle of the spool and avoid jamming.

Print it.
Position the it 3 cm down the entry of the white filament tube at the back of your replicator . Smaller side up, Larger side, downward. There's a right and left version to minimize filament strain from spool
One underneath each of your tube entry.

author: KEVINhenderson

description.text: This is  a mini Foosball table.

I used inventor to make a Foosball table. Then I drew the Foosball players and the Foosball rods, then I added stoppers so that the rod does not pop out of the table, and I added handles. Disclaimer: This is my first build so i am not sure that it will work. Also ball not included

Objectives: How to build a Foosball table Audiences: Children Aged 5-6. Can probably be scaled up, but I am not sure that it will stand properly due to the cube-squared law. Preparation: How to use Inventor. Steps:
  • Make a rectangle and extrude it.
  • Make a smaller rectangle on that rectangle and extrude it inwards. That will be your field.
  • Make goals.
    -Make holes on the side of the field so that the rods can go through. Make the holes a tiny bit larger than the rod.
    -Make the rods, and design the players so that the rod goes to the players.
  • Put the rod with the players in the foosball table.
  • Make stoppers for foosball table rods so that they do not come off.
    • Results:
    You should have a foosball table. Maybe grade on if it works.

author: dojohnso

description.text:
This project is submitted as an entry to the New Museum Challenge.  This  project has yet to be printed or tested but it attempts to demonstrate the feasibility of printing a custom designed shoe.  I do not presently own a 3D printer and this is the first prototype model so there is much experimentation to be done to work out the kinks.
The object, as it is shown, is a babyâ€™s shoe or sandal which potentially could be scaled up to larger versions as a child grows up.  My kids seem to be growing up and out of their shoes and sneakers  everytime I turn my head. I am hoping 3d printers scale up and follow this same trend in time to print larger shoes. 
The feet could be scanned using a standard flatbed scanner and then imported into a CAD program to scale shoe design to fit.  The kids could take part in designing there own shoes adding color, embossments or cutouts to the sides or the treads.  This printed shoe is a derivative of the conventional shoe which you need to settle for the design offered.  This gives the power to the people to create their own when they need it.
I suppose the shoe or sandal could be entirely made with the 3D printer but if made with Sugru it gives the shoe traction and comfortable at the same time.  Maybe a good name might be "Shoegru".
P.S.  Baby needs a new pair of shoes ..... daddy needs a new 3D printer...

Once the parts have been printed the shoe is to be assembled in layers in the following manner:
  • Place shoe bottom on a non-stick surface.
  • Mold Sugru (of your favorite color) into a thin layer (4mm to 6mm thick) and inlay into the top of the shoe bottom.
  • Then place the shoe insert part on top of the sugru pressing down so that the sugru flows through the holes of the shoe bottom. This will provide the traction for the shoe.
    Note: The shoe bottom could be placed on 3mm spacers to allow for the sugru to protrude further than the edges of the shoe.
  • Next install the shoe straps into the grooves on the "shoe insert" part.
  • Place foot onto shoe and adjust straps according so they in the approximate location to hold foot in place.
  • Once strap location is know then apply another thin layer of sugru on top of the "shoe insert".
  • Place foot in the shoe to mold the sugru to the shape of foot.
    7a. OPTIONAL: Next place a Spenco KIDS COMFORT INSOLES (cut to size if need be) on top of sugru.
  • Manually shape front and rear of shoe slightly before sugru hardens.
  • And latestly add velcro to the strap ends and your done.

comments.text: Very cool. I wonder what shoe size the Replicator can print. Clever using Sugru for comfort/traction. Has anyone tried printing this yet?

This is a GO-PRO mount, made compatible with any GO-PRO hero camera. Only additional piece needed is a metallic nut  in the hexagonal receiver, however this is purely for increased stability and is completely optional. The mount is fully functional without it.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

high

Important When creating the mount it is very important to stay exact to the design when reproducing all measurements. Also, when printing, remember to add supports to all sections to avoid collapse, the supports can easily be removed with an appropriate sized drill bit, sandpaper, and an exacto knife.

Project GO-PRO mount Objectives This project allows a student to work with precise measurements and semi complicated Inventor formatting. through this project one would enhance their skills with measuring extrusions and working angles. audiences This is an entry level project and can be completed by anyone with a basic understanding of the Inventor program. preperation The only things you need before starting this project is the precise measurements of a standard GO-PRO mount, able to be found in this project file as well as taken using calipers, and the Inventor program. Steps This project can be approached from many angles. The route I took was to develop a base first then build up from there. After the basic model was designed, I used the fillet tool to smooth out the edges and make it look nice. Don't be afraid to try new things and mess around with base measurements and constructive techniques, as long as the upper measurements (camera receiver) stay precise. Results Once the mount is completely printed, sanded, and all supports are removed, you should have a functional flat based GO-PRO mount. The true test is to attach a GO-PRO camera to the mount and see how it fits. Make sure to tighten the screw as tight as possible to get the most satisfactory performance possible, and again, to add stability feel free to add a metal bolt into the designated area.

description.text:
The Bombardier CRJ-700 is a regional airliner manufactured by Bombardier and based on the CRJ-200. Calls for a larger airliner were made after the success of the CRJ2. The model is based off of the CRJ-200 with a lengthened fuselage forward and aft of the wings. The engines remain the same as all variants of the CRJ have. The wing has been redesigned with the sweep of the wing minimized on the larger versions. This is an all-in-one print.
Any trouble? Let me know!
Version 1.0.8 - I've added slip fit pegs to the wings.

The model was simple to redesign. One of the great features of the CRJ is it's similarity across all version, making training programs for the airlines easier and cheaper, in terms of upgrading. The fuselage and wing design were the only major changes, with the exception of the fifth inboard pylon added to the wings.
This is a small locker shelf that can be hung from the top or door/side of a locker. It holds a phone, money, etc. There is also a place to wrap/hang your headphones on the side.

Objective Students would be able to learn how to properly extrude small details while also being able to create a unique design. They can make something useful for their own locker. Audience: Anyone with some knowledge of Inventor could make this, but it would be useful for people with metal lockers or somewhere magnetic to hold small items. Preparation: Students will need Inventor and some knowledge of basic tools. Steps: Start by making a rectangle on the XY plane and extrude it just enough to be a sturdy base for your shelf. Then add the other 4 sides of the project. Once you've made the basic shape you can design patterns or small hooks off the side for convenience. Once you've established the shelf, don't forget to extrude a small spot to put a magnet in (the black section is where I extruded for the magnet). Results: You'll end up with a simple shelf that can be hung from the top or door/side of a locker. It can hold anything from a phone to hanging headphones off the side.

author: Zomhad

description.text:
This part is designed to allow you to mount a 1-DIN car stereo into a 2-Din slot. DIN is generally defined as 180X50mm, so a 2-DIN is 180X100mm. Many cars come with a 2-DIN sized manufacturer radio, while many aftermarket radios are 1-Din, necessitating a part to fill the gap in the front panel. In my case the car in question is a 1996 ford explorer with a 2-DIN radio slot. After the stock radio broke a few years ago I got a new radio that came with a mounting kit. After that radio got stolen the insurance sent us a radio that came with a mediocre mounting kit that promptly broke, so I designed and printed my own. The adapter mounts a Pioneer P5100UB head unit into the slot of a 1996 Ford Explorer, however DIN sizes tend to be standardized, making it possible that this unit will work for other vehicles, which is why I decided to post it. Features:
The adapter has a large opening in the front to allow you to store CDs, remotes, papers, etc. There is a little lip on the front to prevent stuff from sliding out when you accelerate. The coolest feature is the three 5mm holes and channel on each side. These are intended for you to insert 3 LEDs and run the wiring through the channel so as to create a neat lighting effect. I found the coolest effect to be from producing the plastic parts entirely in Nuclear Green ABS: http://store.makerbot.com/nuclear-green-abs-1kg-spool-3mm-filament.html
The LEDs were UV: http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=3107633
This creates an effect where the lighting comes almost entirely from the fluorescence of the plastic and is thus much more diffuse and less likely to glare into your eye while driving at night. It's also just very unique looking. Note: In the third image from bottom the apparent double image of the 3 LEDs is caused by reflection off the top plastic surface, showing how shiny it is after treatment with acetone.
The bottom image is how the radio/lighting setup would appear from the vantage point of the driver looking down at night.
The top image of course looks straight in and is far brighter than the driver would see. Still it is important for safety reasons to wire it to an external switch rather than just wiring it to the ignition or the instrument light control so that it can be switched off manually if it becomes too bright or distracting.

Print out all the parts except for the one labeled "assembled". This part is for reference only. Attach the parts together in the manner shown by the "assembled" file. Most types of glue should work, however I strongly recommend using ABS (of the same color) dissolved in acetone. I also recommend lightly brushing the interior with this paste to cover up any seams, as well as applying a thickish coating to the outside of the part for strength (you won't see that part anyway) Once the parts are assembled, acquire your LEDs of the chosen color and wire them up so that they can run on car voltage (12V w/engine off, up to 14.5V with engine on). The wiring you choose will depend on the type of LEDs you use. In my case I used UV leds with a voltage rating listed as being from 3.3-4.0V. I wired each side of three in series and the two sides in parallel with eachother. The desired forward current is 20mA, so I used a series resistance in each strand of 168Î© as follows:
voltage drop of 3.7V3LED (series) = 11.1V
14.5-11.1=3.4V Volts that we need to drop to protect the LED
Forward current in LED=20mA
so R=3.4V/0.02A=170Î©
I had 100Î© and 68Î© resistors available at my local radio shack, so each series string of LEDs consisted of 1100Î© resistor, 168Î© resistor, and 3UV LED. Two of these strings are run in parallel off of the supply to the car battery and a switch breaking both circuits wired to the outside and mounted under the dash. I recommend wiring the resistors some distance from the LEDs so that you only have to run two wires through the little channel that leads to the back. Be sure to use lots of electrical tape and/or heat-shrink tubing to insulate all the wiring to prevent any risk of shorting and fires. The total current draw is 0.04A with the engine running, less when running off battery. That means it uses only 0.48W of power and can be left on for quite awhile if desired. Once the lighting and wiring is succesfully attached and tested, place the radio on top of the plastic piece and slide both into the radio slot of the car where they should lock in place/hold in place with friction. The cross-braced portion faces up, and the opening out. Some radios have screw holes for attachment purposes and it may be advisable to design small adapters to allow these to screw to the plastic unit.

title: Y Axis Nut trap for Aluminum Heated bed for Makerfarm Pegasus

description.text:
This is a mockup of something to make leveling your bed platform more easily. 
It traps the nut needed to secure the heated bed to the aluminum platform and lets you level it without the need of a wrench. just use the screw to make adjustments on the go.
This isn't even remotely close to be used as I don't have accurate dimensions yet.
So please don't use this part just yet. Will be updated when i've printed and tested it out.

title: lasercutting - wall mounted cable holder / Wandhalterung für Kabel

description.text:
ENGLISH:
These are SVG CAD files to make a wooden cable holder with a CNC laser cutter to store cables on a wall. It was originally designed by and in HOBBYHIMMEL in 2015 in Germany with the open source software Inkscape (https://inkscape.org/)
We made it to fit holes in a steel beam in the shop hall. We used M8 ISO metric screws. Just edit the holes in the file ;)
  • fingers suitable for 2.9 mm thick HDF boards
  • just stick it together as in the photos
  • pictures show a model made with an Epilog Laser Zing 24 (30 W)
    • This work is licensed by HOBBYHIMMEL under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. CC-BY-SA HOBBYHIMMEL - Die Offene Werkstatt
    http://hobbyhimmel.de
    https://www.facebook.com/hobbyhimmel.stuttgart/ ===
    GERMAN:
    Das sind SVG CAD Daten um eine Wandhalterung für viele Kabel mit einem Lasercutter herzustellen. Originaldesign 2016 by HOBBYHIMMEL in Stuttgart mit dem Open Source Tool Inkscape (https://inkscape.org/de)
    Wir ham's angepasst an einen Stahlträgern mit Löchern und haben M8 Schrauben verwendet. Mit inkscape kann man die Löcher anpassen.
  • Steckfingertoleranzen passend für 2.9 mm Hartfaserplatten
  • einfach zusammenstecken, wie auf den Fotos und M8 Schrauben mit Muttern verwenden, oder die Löcher in der Datei anpassen ;)
  • Die Fotos zeigen ein Exemplar, hergestellt mit einem Epilog Laser Zing 24 (30 W)
    • Dieses Werk von HOBBYHIMMEL - Die Offene Werkstatt ist lizenziert unter einer Creative Commons Namensnennung - Weitergabe unter gleichen Bedingungen 4.0 International Lizenz. CC-BY-SA HOBBYHIMMEL - Die Offene Werkstatt
    http://hobbyhimmel.de
    https://www.facebook.com/hobbyhimmel.stuttgart/

comments.text: Very useful ,Thanks for sharing your design.
